message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The x-ray of the chest shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, which is a common finding in sarcoidosis. Among the options, only a low serum CD4+ T-cell count is associated with sarcoidosis. Positive interferon-gamma release assay is seen in tuberculosis, low serum angiotensin-converting enzyme levels are not specific to any condition, and positive anti-dsDNA antibody testing is seen in systemic lupus erythematosus. The presence of tender, erythematous nodules on both shins is consistent with erythema nodosum, which is also commonly seen in sarcoidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient may have sarcoidosis, which is suggested by the lung symptoms, skin nodules, and x-ray findings. Sarcoidosis is often associated with hypercalcemia, which can cause constipation and fatigue. Low serum CD4+ T-cell count is common in sarcoidosis. Positive interferon-gamma release assay is seen in tuberculosis, not sarcoidosis. Low serum angiotensin-converting enzyme levels are seen in some cases of sarcoidosis, but not always. Positive anti-dsDNA antibody testing is associated with autoimmune diseases such as lupus, which would not explain the patient's symptoms in this case.

Low serum CD4+ T-cell count is often seen in sarcoidosis and can lead to various symptoms including shortness of breath, cough, and fatigue. The other options do not correspond to the symptoms or findings in this patient.

Positive interferon-gamma release assay is associated with tuberculosis, not sarcoidosis. Low serum angiotensin-converting enzyme levels are unlikely in sarcoidosis. Positive anti-dsDNA antibody testing is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, not sarcoidosis.

Low serum angiotensin-converting enzyme levels are seen in some sarcoidosis cases, but is not the most likely finding in this patient. Positive anti-dsDNA antibody testing is seen in autoimmune diseases, such as lupus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings suggest sarcoidosis, which is a disease characterized by noncaseating granulomatous inflammation. Among the options, only a low serum CD4+ T-cell count is associated with sarcoidosis. Positive interferon-gamma release assay may suggest tuberculosis. Low serum angiotensin-converting enzyme levels are sometimes seen in chronic sarcoidosis. Positive anti-dsDNA antibody testing suggests systemic lupus erythematosus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing symptoms of sarcoidosis with tender nodules on both shins and a possible Lofgren's syndrome (injected conjunctivae, erythema nodosum, and bilateral hilar adenopathy). Among the options, only a low serum CD4+ T-cell count is associated with sarcoidosis. The other options are more indicative of other conditions, such as tuberculosis (positive interferon-gamma release assay), systemic lupus erythematosus (positive anti-dsDNA antibody testing), or ACE inhibitor use (low serum angiotensin-converting enzyme levels).
